stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data. Select the 3 most likely findings that require the MOST immediate attention regarding potential lithium toxicity.

tabs.name: SBAR
tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: 07:00 S: Patient is Jane Doe, a 54-year-old female admitted yesterday at 16:00 for bipolar disorder exacerbation. She has been on lithium for several years. 07:00 B: Patient presented with increased manic symptoms including racing thoughts, pressured speech, and decreased need for sleep. Lithium dose was adjusted yesterday. Baseline serum lithium level yesterday at 17:00 was 0.8 mEq/L. Patient also takes lisinopril for hypertension. 07:00 A: Patient appears increasingly confused this morning. She is experiencing some mild nausea. Noted a new onset of tremors. Vital signs are stable. 07:00 R: Recommend checking a current serum lithium level immediately and notifying the physician of these changes. Assess neurological status frequently. Consider holding the next dose of lithium pending lab results. Monitor for worsening symptoms. Maintain hydration.

tabs.name: Vitals
tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: BP: 130/80 mmHg, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 37.0°C (98.6°F), SpO2: 98% on room air

tabs.name: Labs
tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Yesterday at 17:00: Serum lithium: 0.8 mEq/L, Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, BUN: 15 mg/dL, Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL

tabs.name: Exam
tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Alert and oriented to person and place only. Speech is slurred. Noted coarse tremors in both hands. Muscle twitching observed. Reflexes are 3+ and hyperactive in bilateral lower extremities. Skin is warm and dry. Mucous membranes are tacky.

tabs.name: MAR
tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Lithium Carbonate 300 mg PO TID (last dose given at 00:00), Lisinopril 10 mg PO daily

rationale.option_1: CORRECT: Coarse hand tremors are an early sign of lithium toxicity and should be addressed promptly.
rationale.option_2: INCORRECT: Mild nausea can be a side effect of lithium, but it is less concerning than neurological symptoms at this stage.
rationale.option_3: CORRECT: Slurred speech indicates neurological involvement and is concerning for lithium toxicity.
rationale.option_4: INCORRECT: A serum lithium level of 1.0 mEq/L is within the therapeutic range (0.6-1.2 mEq/L), however, given the new onset of symptoms, toxicity should be suspected.
rationale.option_5: CORRECT: Muscle twitching and hyperreflexia are indicative of neurological excitation from lithium toxicity and require immediate attention.
rationale.option_6: INCORRECT: Diarrhea can contribute to dehydration and exacerbate lithium toxicity but is not as immediately concerning as neurological symptoms.
rationale.option_7: INCORRECT: Increased thirst can be a side effect of lithium but is not as concerning as the neurological symptoms at this stage.
rationale.correct: Clinical rationale pending deep clinical alignment.

clinicalPearls: Early signs of lithium toxicity include coarse tremors, slurred speech, and muscle twitching. Neurological symptoms are more concerning than gastrointestinal symptoms. A lithium level within the therapeutic range does not rule out toxicity in the presence of new symptoms.
questionTrap: The question trap is that the lithium level is 1.0 mEq/L (therapeutic range), but the patient is demonstrating new neurological symptoms. Students must recognize the change from baseline and prioritize the neurological symptoms. Focus on 'new onset' symptoms.
mnemonic: Think ' Tremor Speech Twitch' for early signs of lithium toxicity requiring immediate attention.
